page.title: 18ST. NICHOLAS CHURCH PLUCKLEY
page.content: Pluckley was recorded in the Domesday book of 1086 as Pluchlei. The parish includes the now extinct one of Pevington and the hamlets of Ford Mill and Rooting Street. 1093 is the first recorded appointment of a rector at St. Nicholas, Pluckley. Though the present 13th century church is built on the site of former ones. The north wall of the church is all that remains of the Norman church. At the junction of the nave and the chapel is a low stopped window which was known as a Leper's window. Much restoration took place in 1852 when 6 bells were recast for the belfry. The church suffered bomb damage during the second world war when a V1 Flying Bomb landed nearby. A modern north window depicting the annunciation, replaced the original.
